author: 0x1984
content: I saw one of the main concern is IO and storage growth. But to limit gas limit to artificially cap that is not good engineering. Today NVMe can be bought $200 for 2TB. Make it a hardware requirement and go with it. Hardware still advances every a few years and we can ride with it

author: daniellehrner
content: 2TB is already pretty much standard. 4TB is slowly becoming the go to choice for home stakers.

author: daniellehrner
content: There are ways that we could go forward without burdening home stakers more. EIP 6110 together with 4444 would remove big parts of the history from the nodes, which takes up most of the storage. After those raising the gas limit would be much easier.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the much more important question that no one seems to want to talk about is figuring out what exactly the goals/purpose of Ethereum is.  What are we trying to build here?  If the goal is to build a low cost financial derivatives platform, then cranking the gas limit way up makes a ton of sense.  If the goal is to build a censorship resistant base layer that people can reliably fall back on when confronted with censorship of nation states, then the gas limit should arguably go down rather than up.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we only care that *staking* is censorship resistant (people who have >32 ETH saved up), that results in very different calculations than if we care that usage by *users* is censorship resistant (people who are spending $1-$2 in transaction fees to send ETH to family once a month despite being censored by their government and RPC providers).

author: daniellehrner
content: In the end our job is to find a middle ground with acceptable trade-offs. The rollup-centric scaling roadmap requires that people can afford to fall back on L1, in case a L2 rugs them. If I have $100 on an L2 and a tx on L1 costs $200 I inherit security, liveness & censorship resistance from L1 only in theory, because economically it makes no sense to get my money out. So my concern is more to make L2s safe we need "reasonable" tx costs on L1. For this IMO we will need to sacrifice some decentralisation.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> In the end our job is to find a middle ground with acceptable trade-offs.
I don't think everyone agrees (at all) on just how much we should care about the two sides of this trade-off.   Some believe we shouldn't sacrifice any censorship resistance to achieve increased usage, others think we should sacrifice just about everything to achieve adoption.

author: sky.cactus
content: Separately, there is no way to know how much prices will decrease with an increase in gas limit.  One can even construct a plausible narrative where gas prices go *up* when the gas limit increases (new use cases open up that may bring in a new demographic of user that in aggregate results in a gas price increase).

author: daniellehrner
content: You are totally right we can not predict that. But we haven't touched the gas limit in 2+ years and the situation hasn't improved. I think it's time to try something else. 4844 effectively is a gas limit increase (even though it's for blobs), I definitely think we can see how that plays out before any other decisions.

author: jgm
content: The point that we need to see the impact of 4844 before pushing for gas limit changes is an important one.  We're about to increase CPU, network, and storage requirements on all nodes with deneb/cancun,

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think we should be "just trying things" that come at the cost of censorship resistance.  We should have either very good evidence in advance, an experiment we can do to gather more data, or a concrete plan to rollback if it turns out we are wrong.

author: potuz
content: I want to reiterate that discussions about increasing the gas limit should not be kept within the execution side of things anymore. It has repercussions on the CL where change or regimes can be triggered if blocks start arriving at 4 seconds. Testing worse case execution times is a fine measurement, testing for state growth as well. But I'd argue that we also need to consider the propagation times on the CL, the economics of targeted reorgs, the interaction with blobs that themselves increase block latency, etc. This is a much more complex problem than simply "checking the worst case scenario for an execution client". In addition, as <@415548822983278593> has been pointing out regularly, increasing the gas limit has interaction and is in some way a competition to increasing the blob count. If we stick to a rollup centric roadmap and data costs continue being the bottleneck, perhaps increasing the blob count is the way to go.

author: jgm
content:
I've been thinking about this, and if we see blob space being heavily utilised then I think that increasing blob count (whilst potentially simultaneously decreasing block gas limit) could fit better with Ethereum's overall move from being general-purpose computation to trust anchor.

Which leads on to the question of if blob count should be a socially agreed-upon value in the same way that block gas limit is today.

author: potuz
content: Making blob count socially aggreable is much harder to accomplish. While I do like the philosophical argument for it, the code complexity of this makes it a no go IMO

author: 0x1984

The goal is not hotly-debated DEI where we want to have every single stakers to present, you only need mainstream ones, as by the end of the day, censorship resistance come from the total number of stakers. For example, 50% of ETH stakers use AWS today, if AWS censors, can they move that into home computer? If the answer is yes, then yes. What is 70% of hardware sales in the market today? NVMe

author: sky.cactus
content: Ethereum isn't built for stakers, it is built for users.  If users can't run their own node, then they can be censored.  Many RPC providers, including the most used ones, censor a non-trivial portion of the global population already.

author: 0x1984
content: stakers have a higher hardware and network requirement, I doubt increase gas limit will cause issue for light node runners. And light node will get lighter

author: potuz
content: shouldn't we have first working lightclients, with reasonable cryptoeconomic security, before trying to argue that stakers' hardware  is what we will be aiming for in the case of full nodes?

author: 0x1984
content: Light client is being workng on, correct? In the meant time, test out the impact of gas limits on existing light client does not hurt. It's a backward-thinking that just because we are afraid of potential impacts on home users then we could not move on. They are there and will not go away

author: potuz
content: This looks to me like the analog of this: "ePBS is being worked on, therefore we can now require that builders have hugely beefy machines since they eventually will be needed by enshrined builders".  I think you can't kick out the user that wants to submit his transaction from his node running on a rPI without a philosophical change in Ethereum. We may be fine accepting that we request our users to have computers with this or that minimum spec. But this is not something we do that now, this is the reason why all those arguments on twitter about validators having at least $83K can afford a $2K computer is completely irrelevant to the question of raising the gas limit
